content.description: A traverse with a nasty mantle. The actual traversing of the slopey lip is a ton of fun.
content.location:
The boulder this problem is on is around the middle of the school yard. The boulder is an area where the cliffs seem to bow inwards. This boulder isn't connected to any other wall or boulder. It almost has a Pac-Man shape to it (or a horizontal dihedral) or which ever analogy best helps you to find this boulder.

This problem starts on the right (north) side of the lip on 2 slopers and continue along above the lip and move left to the apex of the overhang. Mantle carefully.

climbs.name: That Dog Just Ain't Gonna Hunt
climbs.fa: Aaron Furman, Jordan Hill, & Ken Kodys?

content.description:
Start low on the arete at crimpers and move up one move then trend right toward some tiny edges at about mid-height.   Establish your feet then make a hard throw/series of bumps up and left to the thank-god slot.  From here, top out the moderate slab above.

Requires big moves and may be harder for short climbers.  This problem has a very good sequence and movement which sets it apart from other routes at the School Yard.  A neo-classic!
content.protection: Pads and spotters in the corridor formed by the rock 4 feet behind the problem (exactly enough space to squeeze your pad in).
content.location: Uphill on the cliff line from problem #2 (I believe)/the beginning of the School Yard in Davin's book.  Look for an arete right next to a boulder that forms a short corridor that has just enough space to squeeze a regular sized pad (or 2) in.

content.description: Good roof problem that requires good footing and moderate core strength.
content.location:
The boulder this problem is on is around the middle of The Schoolyard. The boulder is an area where the cliffs seem to bow inwards. This boulder isn't connected to any other wall or boulder. The roof is about 4 feet tall but then turns vertical above that for another 4-5 feet. There is a seam running down the center of it.

This particular problem starts UNDER the roof, LEFT of the seam. Sit start on a right hand pinch and a left hand pocket. Move straight up to a small seem and top out to the left. I might note that some of the layered holds are starting to loosen quite a bit; so just watch out.

content.description: Cool problem that goes up this overhanging, leaning block.
content.location: At the southern end of the School Yard, you will see a sandstone boulder that is detached from the wall and it is leaning on the other wall. To find the start of the problem, locate the little "hallway" between main wall and detached boulder. Sit start on the right side of the arete and you're off.

content.description: A real balancy technical face climb with small crimps.
content.location: The vertical face of the leaning block. The problem is northeast facing. Sit start!
